metadata.sermon_start_end: Advent is on the horizon. That means that the theme of judgment is going to come up, and that makes most of us uneasy. We’ve devised all sorts of stratagems to avoid this subject, cutting it out of liturgies, skipping over it in the lectionary, frowning upon it if it [...] Saint Paul writes to us about this in one of the great passages appointed for Advent. Let us gladly hear his words: “So then... since we belong to the day, let us be sober, and put on the breastplate of faith and love, and for a helmet the hope of salvation. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific Bible passage. It functions as a thematic 'speech about the gospel' and judgment, jumping between 1 Thessalonians, various Isaiah passages, and Malachi. It treats the Bible as a source of proof-texts for a concept ('The Great BUT') rather than recreating a specific pericope into a current word.
quotes: Listen again to the prophecy of Isaiah...
Here again is part of today’s reading from I Thessalonians...
This, then, is the place for the great BUT, from Isaiah 54...
In the surpassing Advent passage that ends the Old Testament... Mal. 3:1–3
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Choose one pericope (e.g., 1 Thessalonians 5:1-11) and extract what is unique to THAT text. Stop using other passages as fillers; let the chosen text speak its own specific truth.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is almost no formal exposition of the original context or linguistic nuances of the primary texts. The preacher mentions the 'day of the Lord' and 'children of light' but does not explain what these meant for the Thessalonians or the historical context of Isaiah's exiles.
quotes: Whether this is a literal concept of hell or not can be debated.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Utilize original languages and historical-critical knowledge to explain the specific tension in the text for its first readers before moving to modern application.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest part, though it leans heavily on psychology. The preacher identifies a specific contemporary idol: the 'God who never judges.' However, it remains somewhat general regarding the 'zeitgeist' by focusing on seminary anecdotes from 1972.
quotes: One of the idols of our own time is the idol we have made of a God who never judges anyone or anything.
The god of 'whatever works for you' is certainly one of the idols of our era.
I remember political correctness very well from my first days in seminary in 1972...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Make the application more concrete to the current year and the specific social/political reality of the congregation, rather than relying on 40-year-old memories.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Because there is so little actual exposition, the 'interwovenness' is more of a thematic tapestry. The hearer is drawn into a psychological reflection rather than being drawn into the biblical text itself.
quotes: The real theological problem here is that we have lost sight of the fact that an act of judgment may very well be an act of liberation.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Structure the sermon so that the movement of the text (the 'exegesis') dictates the movement of the application, rather than using the text to support a pre-conceived psychological point.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The categories of misery (sin/idolatry), redemption (judgment as healing), and gratitude (sober living) are present in the background. The preacher correctly identifies misery as 'misery before God' (idolatry).
quotes: Something has to be done about the human heart, which constantly misleads and deceives.
It is our redeemed self that he loves and promises to make whole in us, but not without judgment...
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'gratitude' section. The ending is a bit abrupt; the transition from being judged to 'building one another up' needs more theological weight.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon takes the possibility of being 'lost' seriously, which Dekker values. It critiques the liberal tradition that ignores judgment. However, the 'two ways' are somewhat blurred by the focus on the 'BUT' which seems to suggest everyone is eventually 'healed' regardless of the way taken.
quotes: God being who he is, he cannot allow evil to exist forever.
The two ways bring man as willing and responsible being to discussion... [Dekker Thesis 6]
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Clarify the 'narrow way.' If judgment is a 'refiner's fire,' what does it mean to be 'lost' in the sense of failing to answer God's calling?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos. The preacher emphasizes the two natures (Pantokrator/Judge and the one who loved us to the last breath). Grace is presented as the context of judgment.
quotes: Everything depends on what we know of Jesus Christ and his second coming in glory...
He is the one who will judge the living and the dead, and that we will be saved from ourselves by the one who has loved us...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just the 'Judge' at the end, but the one through whom the 'specific text' speaks its unique word.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18.5 minutes, the sermon falls just short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. While it covers many themes, it lacks the 'breadth' of deep exegesis required for true 'depth.'
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the time spent on the specific biblical text's original context to reach the 20-minute threshold and provide more substantive depth.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily in its formal structure: it is a thematic essay rather than an exposition of a specific Bible passage. It lacks rigorous exegesis (Greek/Hebrew/Context) and jumps between too many texts. However, it succeeds in its substantive challenge to modern idolatry and its refusal to shy away from the 'misery' of judgment and the necessity of Christ as Judge.
strengths: Theological courage in addressing judgment and wrath against the 'zeitgeist' of non-judgmentalism.
Strong psychological integration that views judgment as a 'negative moment in service of the positive.'
Clear Christocentric focus on the second coming.
weaknesses: Lack of a single, specific biblical pericope; it is too 'general' in its use of Scripture.
Absence of formal exegesis and original context analysis.
Duration is slightly too short to achieve the 'breadth' Dekker demands.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate theological speech, but it is not a 'sermon' according to Dekker’s strict formal definition because it lacks the 'exposition of a specific Bible passage.' It prioritizes a thematic idea over the recreation of the written Word into a new, current word from one text.
